H0.text: They will stop producing energy because wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

H1.text: They were formed millions of years ago, so wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

H2.text: They are always available to produce energy, which is why wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

H3.text: They take millions of years to start producing energy, which is why wind and water are examples of renewable energy sources.

A4.text: Renewable energy is energy made from renewable natural resources that are replenished on a human timescale.

A5.text: Wind power generation can vary significantly not only day-to-day, but even month-to-month.

A6.text: Wind power consumes no fuel, and emits no local air pollution, unlike fossil fuel power sources.

A7.text: In most regions, wind power generation is higher in nighttime, and in winter when solar power output is low.

A8.text: The limitation of the run‑of‑river project is the decreased efficiency of electricity generation because the process depends on the speed of the seasonal river flow.

A9.text: Water can be considered a renewable material when carefully controlled usage and temperature, treatment, and release are followed.

A10.text: Desalination of seawater is considered a renewable source of water, although reducing its dependence on fossil fuel energy is needed for it to be fully renewable.

A11.text: In 2024, renewables accounted for over 30% of global electricity generation and are projected to reach over 45% by 2030.

A12.text: Solar energy can only be captured during the day, and ideally in cloudless conditions.

A13.text: any positive rate of exploitation will eventually lead to the exhaustion of earth's finite stock

A14.text: Sustainable development requires that human activity only uses nature's resources at a rate at which they can be replenished naturally

A15.text: Renewable power generation technologies accounted for around half of all new power generation capacity additions globally.
